title: The best of both in Bulgaria as towns untouched by time cosy up to modern resorts
text:
The best of both in Bulgaria as towns untouched by time cosy up to modern resorts It’s rare to find a part of Europe that is affordable for many and also offers culture, history and scenery Share Comments By John Shammas 07:00, 6 FEB 2017 Lifestyle Bulgaria is the best of both (Photo: Getty) daily Something immediately strikes you when you arrive at the lovely old town of Nessebar, on Bulgaria’s Black Sea coast . A contrast.
Nessebar is a ­centuries-old Unesco World Heritage Site with historic buildings and fortifications.
Yet just across the water is Sunny Beach, the country’s wildly popular modern holiday resort and certainly not a place that Unesco is likely to list any time soon.
Nessebar is on a peninsula – it was an island until a short causeway linked it to the mainland – and while only a short distance from the commercial hotspot, it feels a world away.
Known as the Pearl of the Black Sea, it is a living museum that reflects 3,000 years of history as it was settled, fought over, conquered and settled again.
Nessebar is a centuries old resort (Photo: Getty) Streets are thronged with tourists admiring the churches – Saint Sofia is impressive – and landmarks, while restaurants with stunning views are in no short supply.
It is also packed with the quirky and occasionally tacky tourist shops. Pop into a Russian doll shop and you’ll spot ones with faces of Stalin, Lenin and Putin.
Once you’ve “done” Nessebar, head inland on a journey through the Blue ­Mountains with our tour operator, Balkan Holidays.
It’s a two-hour trip from Nessebar through Burgas, the country’s fourth-largest city, via vineyards and spiralling up secluded roads to the hidden village of Zheravna.
Towns are untouched by time (Photo: Getty) It acted as a retreat for ­Bulgarians escaping Ottoman rulers who refused to let them practise their Christian faith.
And it is stunningly preserved, with a tour of its cobbled streets and 200 wooden houses, all built between the 18th and 19th century, making for an almost alien ­experience.
The mountain village has a population of just over 400 and the climax of our visit was at Saint Nicholas Church, built in 1834.
It is not just the villages that appear untouched by time.
Coastline of the old town of Nessebar (Photo: iStockphoto) On our way back, we passed through a town that seemed to still be recovering from the Soviet era, with residential “blocks” simply given numbers. A stark reminder of the struggles Bulgarians have endured.
Our base was the five-star Sol Nessebar Palace, a five-minute walk from the old town.
Aimed at families, it has excellent facilities, including two large pools and a water park.
The all-inclusive package offers a main restaurant plus Spanish, German and Italian options. There’s an enthusiastic animation team who keep kids happy, allowing parents to relax.
There are stunning modern resorts It’s rare to find a part of Europe that is affordable for many and also offers culture, history and scenery.
And who wouldn’t want a Putin doll?
